subject: Ethics
title: Informed Consent in Trials
description: A 60-second lesson on Informed Consent in Trials.

hook.text: A volunteer signed a thirty-page consent form for a drug trial. Later she admitted she understood almost none of it.

buildup.text: Consent forms grew longer after scandals, packed with legal language meant to protect institutions, not patients.

discovery.text: Studies show most trial participants cannot accurately describe the risks they agreed to just hours earlier.

twist.text: Simpler forms improve understanding but lawyers warn they expose researchers to lawsuits.

climax.text: True consent means genuine understanding, not just a signature on paper.

punchline.text: A signature means nothing if comprehension never happened.

quiz.question: What is a key problem with consent forms in clinical trials?
options: They are too short to cover risks
Most participants cannot accurately describe the risks they agreed to
They are only required in certain countries
